fields.abstract: The film follows an annual 10-day-long walking Pilgrimage in the Ukraine dedicated to and organized by Ukrainian labour migrants and their families. During 260 km walk, the participants attempt to fight the guilt of leaving and state's demonization of migrants. In the context of  crumbling trust in the Ukrainian state, the pilgrims attempt to organize through the institution of the church instead.

fields.title: Roadside Radiation
fields.abstract: With stories and impressions from an alienation zone in Chernobyl, Ukraine, Roadside Radiation portrays different fates of its past and present residents and researchers in this way the complex human consequences of Chernobyl catastrophe: a place of collective loss but also of individual survival.

fields.title: Sonita
fields.abstract: Sonita is an 18-year-old undocumented Afghan immigrant living in the poor suburbs of Tehran. She is a feisty, spirited, young woman who fights to live the way she wants, as an artist, singer, and musician in spite of all the obstacles she confronts in Iran and her conservative patriarchal family. In harsh contrast to her goal is the plan of her family, strongly advanced by her mother, to make her a bride and sell her to a new family. The price for her hand right now is about US $9,000. What’s more, women aren't allowed to sing in Iran. How can Sonita still succeed in making her dreams come true? Director Rokhsareh Ghaem Maghami ends up personally involved in answering that question, reigniting the discussion as to how documentary makers should relate to their subjects.

fields.title: Spree Hotel
fields.abstract: A former 4 star hotel in one of Germany's most racists area has been turned into a home for asylum seekers. A microcosm which remains with its good and bad properties on a lively village in which the refugees, the social workers and the former hotelier are living together.

fields.title: Stealing a Nation
fields.abstract: Stealing A Nation' is an extraordinary film about the plight of the Chagos Islands, whose indigenous population was secretly and brutally expelled by British Governments in the late 1960's and early 1970's to make way for an American military base. The tragedy, which falls within the remit of the International Criminal Court as 'a crime against humanity', is told by Islanders who were dumped in the slums of Mauritius and by British officials who left behind a damning trail of Foreign Office documents.

fields.title: Reunion: Memories of Survival
fields.abstract: In October 1990 two hundred elderly Jewish women travel to Allendorf, Germany. Allendorf had been part of the Buchenwald concentration camp during the 2nd World War. The visit brings back the still vivid 45 year-old memories of the deportation and forced labor. The former inmates of the camps tell their stories about the brutality of the SS and gendarme; the indifference of the Hungarians; the murdering of their loved ones; their lives in the yellow star houses and in the ghetto; and the details of the tortures they suffered during their deportation and in the concentration camps.

fields.title: Youth in the North
fields.abstract: For over three decades, Sri Lanka was ravaged by civil war. Although the entire country felt the effects, the Northern Districts bore the brunt of it. Six years on from its conclusion, it is evident for some that the war has yet to come to an end. Many of the displacement camps set up during the conflict still remain and the people who inhabit those camps, especially the youth who harbour high hopes for the future, have been forgotten.

fields.title: Gone is Syria, Gone
fields.abstract: One day Syria decides to leave. She gathers up her words and her personal affairs, her airspace and ground forces, she takes her geopolitical position, and she leaves.

fields.title: Back Home
fields.abstract: In today's Crimea, a peninsula on the northern coast of the Black Sea, some stay, but many go. Public concern is mixed, in some quarters people appear euphoric, but in others a sense of regret appears to govern emotion. However, one thing is concrete and inescapable, life has changed dramatically since Russia annexed Crimea. 'Back Home' asks how exactly it's changed? Simferopol-born Inna Denisova returns to her native city in search of answers. This documentary tells the story of one woman's return home to follow the lives of artists and friends in and among the vivid backdrop of a deeply divided society.

fields.title: Conversation with Odysseus
fields.abstract: In 1943 a 17-year-old Ukrainian, Anastasia Gulej, was sent to Auschwitz. At the beginning of 1945 she was transferred to Bergen Belsen. She survived through both death camp placements and moved back to Kiev. She now speaks on the behalf of those that perished there against the backdrop of political events following the Kiev Maidan Revolution.

fields.title: Not My Job
fields.abstract: Searching for a better life, Farrukh leaves his wife and child behind in Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan, and joins his father, mother, and two younger brothers in the outskirts of Moscow. To bring home a few rubles, the young Tajik illegal immigrant works odd jobs but dreams of becoming a famous actor. He is invited by a film crew to play an immigrant falsely accused of a man’s murder, but reality proves stranger than fiction when he causes another man’s death in a road accident and lands in prison. The camera closely follows this tragic character as he is trying to find the midway between respect for his traditionalist parents and the will to integrate into a universe where no one welcomes him.
